article.title: Constraints on core-collapse supernova progenitors from explosion site integral field spectroscopy

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure shows the relative frequency of each SN type in the current sample compared to that of LOSS. What can we conclude about the relative frequency of hydrogen-rich and hydrogen-poor SNe in both samples?
choices: The relative frequency of hydrogen-rich SNe is significantly higher in the current sample.
The relative frequency of hydrogen-poor SNe is significantly lower in the LOSS sample.
The relative frequency of both hydrogen-rich and hydrogen-poor SNe is consistent in both samples.
The relative frequency of SNe Ic is significantly higher in the LOSS sample.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure shows a histogram of SN host distances in the sample. What is the approximate median distance of the SN hosts, and what does this imply about the spatial resolution achieved?
choices: The median distance is ~40 Mpc, implying a spatial resolution of ~200 pc.
The median distance is ~18 Mpc, implying a spatial resolution better than 100 pc.
The median distance is ~30 Mpc, implying a spatial resolution of ~150 pc.
The median distance is ~10 Mpc, implying a spatial resolution better than 50 pc.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure compares the cumulative metallicity distributions of different SN subtypes. What is the main finding regarding metallicity differences between SN subtypes?
choices: SNe Ic have a significantly higher metallicity distribution compared to other subtypes.
SNe IIn show a significantly lower metallicity distribution compared to other subtypes.
Normal CCSN events have similar metallicity distributions to SLSNe and SNe Ic-BL.
No significant metallicity differences are observed among distinct supernova types.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure illustrates the evolution of different age indicators used in the study. What age range does the CO 2.3μ absorption line primarily probe, and what does this imply about the stellar populations it can constrain?
choices: CO 2.3μ probes ages less than 8 Myr, revealing information about young, massive stars.
CO 2.3μ probes ages greater than 8 Myr, revealing information about older, lower mass stars.
CO 2.3μ probes all ages, providing a comprehensive view of the stellar population.
CO 2.3μ probes only the age of the SN progenitor, independent of the surrounding stellar population.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure shows the observed cumulative distribution of log(HaEW) for different SN subtypes. Which SN subtype consistently shows the lowest HaEW, implying an association with older stellar populations?
choices: SNe Ic
SNe Ib
SNe II
SNe IIn

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure presents the observed cumulative distribution of progenitor initial mass for different SN subtypes, as derived from HaEW and stellar evolutionary models. Which SN subtype is associated with the highest progenitor initial mass estimates?
choices: SNe IIn
SNe IIb
SNe Ib
SNe Ic

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure displays various maps of the explosion site of SN 2009dq. Panel (v) shows the pixel statistics for different age indicators. What can be concluded from the comparison between the Bry-CO pixel statistics and the Ha-[NII] pixel statistics?
choices: Strong correlation between Bry and CO indicates they originate from the same stellar population.
Strong correlation between Ha and [NII] suggests they are both tracers of young stellar populations.
Lack of correlation between Bry and CO suggests they probe different stellar populations.
Both (B) and (C) are correct.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure shows the cumulative distribution of host H II region flux and luminosity. What can be concluded about the star formation history at the SN sites based on the dominant H II region type?
choices: The dominance of large, luminous H II regions suggests ongoing, continuous star formation.
The dominance of smaller, less luminous H II regions suggests a closer-to-instantaneous star formation history.
The bimodal distribution of H II regions indicates two distinct populations of SNe.
The H II region properties do not provide any information about the star formation history.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure investigates the number ratios of different SN types in metallicity bins. What does the flat trend observed in the N(SESN)/N(SN II) ratio across metallicity suggest?
choices: Metallicity plays a crucial role in deciding the production of SESNe compared to SNe II.
The production of both SESNe and SNe II is equally affected by metallicity.
Factors other than metallicity are more dominant in driving the production of SESNe.
This ratio does not provide any information about the role of metallicity in SN production.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure compares the observed progenitor initial mass and metallicity of different SN subtypes with single-star stellar evolution predictions. What is the main implication of the significant overlap observed between SN subtypes on the initial mass-metallicity plane?
choices: Single-star evolutionary models accurately predict the progenitor properties of all CCSNe.
Metallicity is the dominant factor in determining the SN type of a massive star.
A strictly single-star progenitor scenario is unlikely, and binary interaction plays a significant role in CCSN production.
The observed overlap is a statistical artifact and does not contradict single-star evolution predictions.
